title: Faculty Circular #55
creator: The Office of Afro-American Affairs
description: This is a document of which the Robert Johnson, president of the Afro-Afro-American Student Association wrote on behalf of that organization to the Faculty Council of Indiana University with a list of demands. Among the demands, they called for the appointment of a major administrator; they asked for a vice-president of Afro American Affairs, the establishment of an institute of Afro-American Studies, campus wide racial sensitivity training and more.
subject: black student publications
notes: This document comes from the unoffical archive of the Neal-Marshall Black Culture Center and at present there is no online finding aid for it

title: Faculty Circular #67
creator: Ad Hoc Committee on Consolidation of Afro-American Programs
description: This is a document which Robert Johnson wrote on behalf of the Afro-Afro-American Students Association and in the larger sense the Ad Hoc Committee on Consolidation of Afro-American Programs and it was sent to the President Joseph Sutton. This report recounts the demands that the Faculty Council decided to acquiesce to, but with modifications, principal among them was the decision to create an Afro-American Institute, to hire an African American administrator but with medication in his position in the institutional bureaucracy and with that a name change. The Faculty Council agreed to name a Vice Chancellor of Afro-African Affairs instead of a Vice-President as the students demanded in Faculty Circular# 55.
subject: black student publications
notes: This document comes from the unoffical archive of the Neal-Marshall Black Culture Center and at present there is no online finding aid for it

title: The Black Wheel V1 N1
creator: The Office of Afro-American Affairs
contributor: Sanders, Charles D. and Perkins, Estella B.
description: The Black Wheel was an organ created for the dissemination of Black news, thoughts, discussion, and are at Indiana University. It was created because the publishers didn’t think that there had been a factual way of reporting happenings across campus until the publication of the Black Wheel
subject: black student publications
notes: In the Black Wheel publications they have Spotllight Series where they highlight important Black figures around campus, and in this issue the Spotlight shown is on Herman Hudson

title: The Black Wheel V.1 N.2
creator: The Office of Afro-American Affairs
description: The Black Wheel was an organ created for the dissemination of Black news, thoughts, discussion, and are at Indiana University. It was created because the publishers didn’t think that there had been a factual way of reporting happenings across campus until the publication of the Black Wheel
subject: black student publications
notes: Of many things that are discussed, the students of the Black Wheel express their enthusiasm for Herman Hudson being elected as the acting Vice-Chancellor of Afro-American Affairs, a person they believed would put pressure on the "man" (top adminstrators) and activate the inert Afro-American Studies Institute

title:
Herman Hudson
A Visual-Biographical Journey of his Arrival to Indiana University Bloomington
contributor: Institute of Digital Arts and Humanities

title: Proposed Neal-Marshall Black Culture Center
creator: Sonja Johnson; Leslie Simpson; Herman Hudson
description: This is the proposal for the Neal-Marshall Black Culture Center. It includes arguments for why the new Center is needed, description of the project, the mission and objectives of teh Black Culture Center, Performance's place in the new Culture Center in the form of the IU. Soul Revue, The African American Dance Company, and the African American Choral Ensemble.  Also, this is not the full proposal, the original is housed at the IU Archives there is also a copy at the Neal-Marshall Black Culture Center Archive. The complete document is 101 pages
subject: a proposal
notes: Discusses its connection to the deparment of African American Studies at IU and outlines how the Culture Center originally planned to house space for the National Council for Black Studies Offices. Also, this is not the full proposal, the original is housed at the IU Archives there is also a copy at the Neal-Marshall Black Culture Center Archive. The complete document is 101 pages.

title: Indiana University Center for The Study of History and Memory: Herman Hudson
creator: ndiana University Center for The Study of History and Memory
description: An interview with Herman Hudson conduced by Elizabeth Marsh for the Oral History Research Center. In this interview Hudson details his upbringing, the various higher educational instutiutions he taught at, how he was selected to be the founding Vice Chancellor for Afro-American Affairs and Chair fo the then deparment of Afro-American Studies deparment, the various diversity initatives he began at IU among other things
subject: interview with herman hudson
source: Center for Documentary Research and Practice
rights: Permission to use is granted but the interview cannot be reproduced in full onlline or in publications

title: The Black Student Voice V.1 N.1
creator: The Office of Afro-American Affairs
description: "The Black Student Voice [was] a weekly publication of the Office of Afro-American Affairs. The office of Afro-American Affairs [was] an ad hoc organization of Black students who [were] dedicated to securing a place of honor and dignity for Black people as human beings." Headlines include "IU Trustees’ Statement Meaningless", "Chairman Makes a Racist Statement", "Athletic Department Challenged", among others.
subject: black student publications

title: History of Afro-American Studies Department Based on a Interview with Dr. Herman [C] Hudosn
description: This is a transcribed interview where Herman Hudson is the  interviewee,  and the Interviewer is unknown. Here Hudson answers questions like "What led to the Creation of the Deparment of Afro-American Studies;" " how long did it take for the faculty to accept the document known as "Facultty Circular #55." That document is the offfical write up of the demands of the Black Studies student activist presented to the University. It also makes plain  what larger societal issues further radicalized the Black students at IU. It also discusses who were the first faculty members of the department.
subject: interview with herman hudson

title: The Black Studies Program: Strategy and Structure
creator: Herman Hudson
publisher: The Journal of Negro Education V.41
description: The document details what is considered by Hudson the "college student revolution" of the 1960s and how that movement made it impossible for the nation to continue to ignore the brutalizing effects of injustice, racism, and war. On top of of the demands made by students during this student revolution, Black studies programs were forwarded as a way to cure some of the ills that plagued the nation. Here Hudson also details why departmental status was the most viable form that a Black Studies initiative could take for institutional legitimacy and staying power.
subject: journal article

title: Black Students Group Aims for Communication
creator: Indiana Daily Student
description: A newspaper article on the origin of the Afro, Afro-American Student's Association (AAASA).  Here Robert Johnson, president of AAASA) describes the threefold aims of the AAASA: first, the improvement of communications between Black Students, secondly, a greater sense of unity between Black students. Thirdly, they prompted greater Black student participation in campus affairs. It is also noted here, that the AAASA was an artistic, education, political, and social organization.
subject: newspaper article
source: Government Information, Maps and Microform Services

title: AAASA President Discusses Negro Objectives
creator: Indiana Daily Student
description: A newspaper article discusses AAASA objectives. Here the AAAASA, through its president, Robert Johnson makes it known that they are not interested in integrating Sigma Chi Instead they mention that they were interested in seeing the formal discriminatory practices that have financial support of the state of Indiana overturned.
subject: newspaper article
source: Government Information, Maps and Microform Services
